results.title: Digital Storytelling workshop : general public (June 2010)
results.creator_credit: Penny Morison, Melanie Steptoe, Jimmy Pasakos, Deborah Horne, Barbara Lemon, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: These five stories were created by members of the general public as part of a Digital Storytelling workshop at ACMI. On the most part, the stories are tributes to the people in the participants families that have been important or inspiring them. They employ a variety of storytelling techniques that best convey the emotion and intention of the stories.

results.brief_description: Four stories as created by members of the general public for Digital Storytelling’s DST Express workshop. These stories, all of less than two minutes, cover life changing events, major lessons and inspirational family members.

results.title: Digging up ancestors
results.brief_description: Investigates the discovery of extensive fossil beds at Koonwarra, Victoria. The beds are estimated to be around 120 million years old. Professor Jim Warren, an expert in fossil research, discusses his work at the beds and demonstrates how much information fossils can give us. Suitable for early secondary levels. Narrated by John Gaden.

results.title: Diggers of the deeps
results.creator_credit: Grant McLean, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A review of the problems created by the decline of the coal-mining industry in Canada, as witnessed in one of the most affected areas of Nova Scotia. The film goes into the mines of Cape Breton to study the question at close range. It shows how high production costs, inadequate mining methods and increased competition threaten not only the livelihood of the Cape Breton miners, but also a large part of Canada’s industrial economy.

results.title: Diggers
results.creator_credit: Frank Thring and Efftee Film Productions
results.brief_description: This was the first feature film of the Melbourne enterprise Efftee Films and was adapted for the screen by Pat Hanna from three sketches from his popular Diggers stage show, which featured two Australian cobbers serving in the AIF in France in 1918. The first episode presents the two friends in their attempts to steal rum from a British Army Store; the second episode shows them relaxing in a French cafe while a fellow digger romances with the waitress; the final episode finds the diggers in hospital feigning illness to escape active duty. Cast includes Pat Hanna and George Moon.

results.title: Digestive system
results.brief_description: A clear explanation of the digestive system illustrating both the mechanical and enzymatic action together with the regulation of the digestive process by hormones and nerves. The digestive system is also related to other bodily systems as well as its functional relationship with the entire body.

results.title: Digestion: Muscular and mechanical movement
results.creator_credit: Beryl Denman Lacey, Frank Wells and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: Deals with the muscular processes involved in the digestion of food. The film demonstrates mechanical and muscular processes of mastication and swallowing; peristalsis in the oesophagus, small intestine, and colour segmentation in the small intestine; contraction waves in the cardiac and pyloric regions of the stomach; absorption of food into the blood from the small intestine, and of water and salts from the colon.

results.title: Digestion. Pt. 2: chemical changes
results.creator_credit: Beryl Denman Lacey and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: An account of the chief changes involved in the chemical breakdown of the main types of foodstuffs during digestion. Shows the secretion of saliva and its action on cooked starch; the gastric glands; secretion of intestinal bile and pancreatic juice and their effect on proteins, carbohydrates and fats; the absorption of nutriment through the villi and lacteals into the blood and its subsequent circulation through the body.
